head.title: Creating a Share Class For Big Buy-and-Holders

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: Creating a Share Class For Big Buy-and-Holders

abstract.p: Vanguard Group plans to introduce new class of low-expense mutual-fund shares for investors who have held $50,000 in a fund account for at least 10 years, or $150,000 for at least three years (M)

block.p: The Vanguard Group plans to reward its largest and most loyal retail customers with a new class of low-expense fund shares.

Under the plan, retail shareholders, including those in individual retirement programs, who have held $50,000 in a fund account for at least 10 years, or $150,000 for at least three years, will be eligible to switch into the new class of shares, called Admiral shares. Any investor with at least $250,000 in a retail fund account can also get in. Conversion to the new share class should not create a tax liability for most investors, the company said.

Administrative expenses will be one-quarter to one-third lower than those of Vanguard's traditional fund shares, already the industry's lowest, John Demming, a Vanguard spokesman, told Bloomberg News.
For example, Admiral shares of the Vanguard Index 500 fund would pay expenses of 0.12 percent a year; ordinary shares of the fund now pay 0.18 percent a year.

''The costs of acquiring and establishing a new account are significant and rising, and in the mutual fund industry those costs are disproportionately borne by long-term shareholders,'' said John J. Brennan, chairman of Vanguard, in a statement. ''In addition, retail shareholders who have maintained sizable accounts for a long period of time and have not caused a fund to incur transaction costs are very desirable.'' Such accounts help hold costs down for all investors, the statement added.

Vanguard investors who do not qualify for Admiral shares would see no change or a ''minimal'' increase in the expense charges they pay, perhaps two or three hundredths of a percentage point, the company told Reuters.
Vanguard plans to offer Admiral class shares on its index funds starting in the fourth quarter, with most of its equity, bond and balanced funds to follow in 2001.
